raw_text:
Brentford v Southampton
 
 Griffin Park
 
 Tuesday, 1 March
 
 1945 GMT
 
 Barry Knight (Kent)
 
 home to Manchester United in the quarter-finals
 
 Midfielder Andrew Frampton and striker Deon Burton are both slight doubts with hamstring injuries, but should be fit Saints are missing their entire first-choice midfield of Jamie Redknapp, Graeme Le Saux, Nigel Quashie and David Prutton. Anders Svensson and Matt Oakley are likely replacements with Kevin Phillips also scheduled to start, with Henri Camara rested.
 
 - Brentford boss Martin Allen: "After conceding eight goals in our last three matches, I have to admit I'm not very confident. "There's no doubt we're the underdogs and after defending so poorly recently it's not looking good. "Southampton have just drawn with the Premiership champions and that makes our task harder than it was already." 
  - Southampton boss Harry Redknapp: "We know they can give us problems. "Brentford have done well but we are the Premiership side and should have the better players. "Staying in the Premiership is our priority. We want to win, of course we do. We'll battle but if it comes to a football match I think we'll win." KEY MATCH STATS 
  - BRENTFORD are the lowest ranked club left in the FA Cup. They're on their best run in the competition since reaching the quarter-finals for the fourth time in their history 16 years ago. Now they have the carrot of the plum draw in the last eight dangling before them. Victory over Premiership strugglers Southampton, would bring the mighty Manchester United to Griffin Park and a gigantic pay day for the sole League One survivors. 
  - Martin Allen's brave side came back from two goals down at St Mary's to earn a deserved replay. Southampton striker Henri Camara scored twice from close range to put the Saints in command, but Isaiah Rankin hit back just before half time, and Sam Sodje headed past a creaky defence on 58 minutes. 
  - The Londoners have conceded six goals in their two subsequent League outings - three each in losing away to Hartlepool and drawing at home to Sheffield Wednesday. But they haven't lost in six League and Cup games on home turf - winning three and drawing three since the reverse to Torquay on Boxing Day. 
  - SOUTHAMPTON go into this tie on the back of an eventful Premiership match with Arsenal on Saturday. An angry David Prutton pushed referee Alan Wiley after being shown the red card, but his side still came back to draw 1-1. It was Saints' fourth stalemate in succession in all competitions, but didn't lift them out of the relegation zone. The retention of their ever present Premier League status must be the number one priority, irrespective of the rewards that success against Brentford would bring. 
  - Victory here would set up a repeat of the 1976 final, when Saints astounded the football world by defeating Tommy Docherty's Manchester United courtesy of Bobby Stokes' famous winner. They also knocked out the Red Devils in 1991 on penalties in the fourth round. But to write another chapter in their FA Cup history, the Solent side must avoid succumbing to lower division opposition for the first time since Rotherham, from the second level, beat them 2-1 in a third round tie at Millmoor on 16 January 2002. Southampton were last humbled by a club from the third tier six years ago. Fulham were then in the Second Division, when they won a third round replay at Craven Cottage 1-0 on 13 January 1999. 
  - To get to within two matches of a second visit to the Millennium Stadium in three years for the final, Harry Redknapp must guide his side past a club 36 places inferior on the League ladder, and a manager 19 years his junior, who played under him at West Ham. HEAD TO HEAD
 
 10th League One
 
 QUARTER-FINALS (four times)
 
 18th PREM
 
 WINNERS (once)
llama3.2:1b:
Brentford v Southampton at Griffin Park on Tuesday, 1 March, 1945 GMT.

Brentford's hopes of reaching the quarter-finals are dashed with injuries to key players Barry Knight and Andrew Frampton. Manchester United will provide a major test in this FA Cup match, given their recent league form.

Southampton face an uphill battle against Brentford, who have overcome lower divisions before. The Saints' top four Premier League status must be a priority in the tie, despite the potential reward of beating one of the biggest teams in English football.

Brentford boss Martin Allen is under pressure to secure the win and avoid being considered the underdogs. Southampton boss Harry Redknapp believes his team can overcome Brentford's defensive play.
llama3.2:3b: Brentford host Southampton in the quarter-finals of the FA Cup at Griffin Park on March 1, 1945. The match pits the lowest-ranked club left in the competition against a Premier League side. Brentford has conceded eight goals in their last three matches and is missing its entire first-choice midfield. Southampton has drawn with Premiership champions Arsenal and will be led by manager Harry Redknapp, who played under Martin Allen at West Ham.
gemma2:2b:
Brentford and Southampton will play in the FA Cup quarter-finals.  Southampton has a higher league standing but Brentford has done well in this competition, having drawn with the Premiership champions recently. This match is significant as it could bring Manchester United to Griffin Park for a huge financial reward. 
 Southampton is facing a difficult task against a lower division team and will need to focus on securing their Premier League status. 
The two teams have played each other many times in the FA Cup, with a history of exciting matches.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Brentford v Southampton is a quarter-final match for the Premier League. Here are key points:

- Brentford are the lowest-ranked club in FA Cup since reaching the quarter-finals in 2016.
- Southampton have won their past five league matches, but are currently losing to Birmingham City.
- Both teams have home ground advantage.
- Key match statistics:
  - Londoners concede six goals in two games.
  - Southampton's first goal comes from an offside error.
qwen2.5:1.5b:
Summary:
Brentford faces Southampton in the FA Cup quarter-final, where Brentford are considered underdogs after a poor recent run, while Southampton aim to secure their Premier League status. Brentford's last four games have resulted in three wins and one draw at home, despite conceding six goals. Southampton won 1-0 against Fulham earlier this season but will look to avoid playing lower division opponents for the first time since 2002. A win would bring Manchester United a significant prize, while Brentford needs to secure passage to Griffin Park's last eight.
qwen2.5:3b: Brentford v Southampton will be held at Griffin Park on Tuesday, March 1st at 1945 GMT. Brentford are the lowest ranked club left in the FA Cup and currently on their best run since reaching quarter-finals 16 years ago. They're aiming to defeat Premiership strugglers Southampton for a potential trip to Manchester United. However, Saints have no choice but to fight as they aim to retain their Premier League status. Key match stats show Brentford's recent poor defensive form and Southampton's ability to draw close matches despite relegation zone struggles. A win would set up a potential repeat of the 1976 final when Southampton beat Manchester United with Bobby Stokes' winner. Despite being from the lower divisions, the history shows they have not lost to any club below League One since their most recent defeat in 2002. Redknapp aims to avoid such an upset for his team's second visit to a Wembley final in three years.
opencoder:1.5b:
Brentford v Southampton

Griffin Park

Tuesday, 1 March

19:45 GMT

Barry Knight (Kent)

home to Manchester United in the quarter-finals

Midfielder Andrew Frampton and striker Deon Burton are both slight doubts with hamstring injuries, but should be fit Saints are missing their entire first-choice midfield of Jamie Redknapp, Graeme Le Saux, Nigel Quashie and David Prutton. Anders Svensson and Matt Oakley are likely replacements with Kevin Phillips also scheduled to start, with Henri Camara rested.

Martin Allen: "After conceding eight goals in our last three matches, I have to admit I'm not very confident. There's no doubt we're the underdogs and after defending so poorly recently it's not looking good. We've won a few games now and we are in the top 20 in the FA Cup." 

Southampton boss Harry Redknapp: "We know they can give us problems. Brentford have done well but we are the Premiership side and should have the better players. We want to win, of course we do. We'll battle but if it comes to a football match I think we'll win." KEY MATCH STATS 

BRENTFORD are the lowest ranked club left in the FA Cup. They're on their best run in the competition since reaching the quarter-finals for the fourth time in their history 16 years ago. Now they have the carrot of the plum draw in the last eight dangling before them. Victory over Premiership strugglers Southampton, would bring the mighty Manchester United to Griffin Park and a gigantic pay day for the sole League One survivors.

SOUTHAMPTON go into this tie on the back of an eventful Premiership match with Arsenal on Saturday. An angry David Prutton pushed referee Alan Wiley after being shown the red card, but his side still came back to draw 1-1. It was Saints' fourth stalemate in succession in all competitions, but didn't lift them out of the relegation zone. The retention of their ever present Premier League status must be the number one priority, irrespective of the rewards that success against Brentford would bring.

Victory here would set up a repeat of the 1976 final, when Saints astounded the football world by defeating Tommy Docherty's Manchester United courtesy of Bobby Stokes' famous winner. They also knocked out the Red Devils in 1991 on penalties in the fourth round. But to write another chapter in their FA Cup history, the Solent side must avoid succumbing to lower division opposition for the first time since Rotherham, from the second level, beat them 2-1 in a third round tie at Millmoor on 16 January 2002. Southampton were last humbled by a club from the third tier six years ago. Fulham were then in the Second Division, when they won a third round replay at Craven Cottage 1-0 on 13 January 1999.

To get to within two matches of a second visit to the Millennium Stadium in three years for the final, Harry Redknapp must guide his side past a club 36 places inferior on the League ladder, and a manager 19 years his junior, who played under him at West Ham.

granite3.1-dense:2b:
Brentford, the lowest-ranked club remaining in the FA Cup, hosts Southampton at Griffin Park on Tuesday, March 1st. Brentford has a history of strong performances at home, winning three and drawing three against lower-division opposition over the past six years. They recently rallied from two goals down to earn a replay against Southampton after a challenging two-match losing streak in League outings.

Southampton, a Premiership club struggling with relegation, drew 1-1 with Arsenal on Saturday due to David Prutton's red card. Their priority is retaining Premier League status, despite the potential financial rewards of an FA Cup victory over Brentford. Southampton has previously defeated Manchester United in a fourth-round match (1976) and in penalties (1991), but must avoid losing to a club 36 places lower on the League ladder for the first time since 2002.

Key points:
- Brentford's form has been inconsistent, conceding six goals in two recent League matches but winning three and drawing three at home over the past six games.
- Southampton is missing key players from their Premiership lineup due to injuries, with Anders Svensson, Matt Oakley, Kevin Phillips, and Henri Camara expected to start.
- Victory for Brentford would set up a repeat of the 1976 FA Cup final against Manchester United and could bring the Premier League champions to Griffin Park in the last eight.
- Southampton's manager, Harry Redknapp, acknowledges Brentford's potential to cause an upset but prioritizes their Premier League status.
reference: Victory over Premiership strugglers Southampton, would bring the mighty Manchester United to Griffin Park and a gigantic pay day for the sole League One survivors.- To get to within two matches of a second visit to the Millennium Stadium in three years for the final, Harry Redknapp must guide his side past a club 36 places inferior on the League ladder, and a manager 19 years his junior, who played under him at West Ham.- SOUTHAMPTON go into this tie on the back of an eventful Premiership match with Arsenal on Saturday.Southampton were last humbled by a club from the third tier six years ago."Brentford have done well but we are the Premiership side and should have the better players.But to write another chapter in their FA Cup history, the Solent side must avoid succumbing to lower division opposition for the first time since Rotherham, from the second level, beat them 2-1 in a third round tie at Millmoor on 16 January 2002.- Brentford boss Martin Allen: "After conceding eight goals in our last three matches, I have to admit I'm not very confident.But they haven't lost in six League and Cup games on home turf - winning three and drawing three since the reverse to Torquay on Boxing Day."Southampton have just drawn with the Premiership champions and that makes our task harder than it was already."The retention of their ever present Premier League status must be the number one priority, irrespective of the rewards that success against Brentford would bring.- The Londoners have conceded six goals in their two subsequent League outings - three each in losing away to Hartlepool and drawing at home to Sheffield Wednesday.Southampton striker Henri Camara scored twice from close range to put the Saints in command, but Isaiah Rankin hit back just before half time, and Sam Sodje headed past a creaky defence on 58 minutes.
